LYNDA KATE SMITH: So, I
have been through this with multiple companies. And I sit back and
I go, oh my God,

do we have product market fit? Or when I'm looking
at a new company to work with, it, again,
is this feeling of, I hope this company
has product market fit.

How do I know? Because at the end
of the day, if you don't have product
market fit, you're just not going to succeed.

So what are the red flags? What are the things
I need to look at when it's early on so
that I can make sure we

go in the right direction? So it's a topic that
I'm passionate about. And I appreciate your
being a part of it.

So in today's session,
what we're really going to be working to look
at is, how do you know?

What tools can I
use to really start understanding what's going
on for the product market fit

perspective? So my objectives
for you today is that you leave this short
little time together

with an appreciation of
how great marketing isn't a substitute. A lot of marketers

It doesn't work. I'll share a great

here, recently. Give you a rubric,
and understanding,

a way to be able to look for
what those red flags are. What are the questions
I can ask early so that you can
see whether you're

experience matters,

and how companies manage this. Because a lot of people
forget that experience is actually part of
the product offering

that we're going to do is start with, how does
one define a product?

I've worked with,

setting, where we have professional

as a person that works on this

They really focus

that actually are so important. Now, this has been around
for a very long time.

And my theory is, if it's
not broke, let's not fix it. This is something
that Jeff Barr brought

to market a long time ago. And I love it. It's the Construct
of the Whole Product. A whole product is everything,
that minimum set of products

and services that
you need to fulfill on the compelling
reason a person is even looking at
what you have to offer.

Give you a quick example I

that really makes me go,

The fact that you

of telephony, which

software-based world. But those APIs weren't enough.

things like telephone

numbers, part of the product. On the services side,

consumer products.

fit in the earliest days?

ideas, these questions

for your ideas, and really make
sure you're pushing yourself, you're pushing your
co-founders, or if you are just

a member of the company,
it's OK to push and ask. Because ultimately,
the company is only going to last if it
has product market fit.

So how do you figure this out? Well this is a tried
and true way to do this.

You need to get out and
listen to the market. You need to get out
and talk to people. And you need to learn.

And you need to
constantly refine. And you're going to do
this over and over again. And again, you may go, well,
that's really common sense.

Everyone does it. They don't. I have worked with companies
on a consulting basis, where the co-founder had this amazing
idea, was passionate about it,

got a few other people who had
money, passionate about it. Figured they'd figure
out things, like pricing

and all that later. And didn't keep going
back to the market to get that valuable input.

Got the product all the
way out, launched it. And all the things that
were wrong with the product,

they could have been learned. They could have
been learned early. There wasn't enough
communication with the marketplace.

So rule number
one, get out there and talk to the
customers, whether that's

in person, virtually,
via various companies and third parties that
can do it for you. There's a lot of
inexpensive online tools now

that can help you with it. But you got to
talk to the world. All right, now we're going
to go for the little snack

here on a customer experience
because I'm passionate about it and I do think, again,
is that additional layer

on the whole product. And especially,
as I said before, if you are in a
product or a market

where there are other
products people might select, either direct competitor
or alternatives to what you're
doing, the experience

can actually save the day. So when we think about
the customer experience, again, coming back
to a definition,

it's a blend of the company's
physical performance and the emotions that are evoked
that intuitively lead to people

wanting to be a
part of this brand. And it happens across
all the touchpoints they're going to have.

And so customer experience
is one part reality, sanity check, but it is
also one part emotion.

And so thinking about how
you're touching all of that becomes very important.

And it's interesting. There are companies that
excel in this idea of customer experience. And, by the way,
amazing Google searches,

top five companies for this,
top five companies for that. You can always find great
marketing content around it.

But I really kind of
resonated with these. And I went, Zappos, yeah,
purchased by Amazon,

ultimately. But they were really an amazing
customer experience company. And the way they did it was they
started with creating a culture

around this. They enabled and
empowered their employees to be a part of the
experience, super important.

Workday, here we are in a B2B
enterprise software type space. But they have been
really successful.

And it's because they have a
long term, very clear vision for what customer
success looks like.

And everyone in the
company understands that. And that goes from how the
product has to perform, to how support has to act,
how people have to come

into contact with the product. Silicon Valley Bank, never
thought about a bank customer

experience before. Well, they take
it very seriously. And what they really work
to do is listen carefully

to the customers. And then they act
on what they hear. They get answers
back out to people.

All right Nordstrom, you always
see these guys written up. I don't shop there,
personally, but I understand it's a great experience.

And the way they do it is they
treat the customers as the way they would want to be treated. And they do give their
employees on the show floor,

on the store floor, all
sorts of opportunity to be awesome hosts to
the people that come in.

And they take that
very seriously to differentiate because,
here again, there are lots of department
stores you can go to,

if that's your thing. And then Virgin, I
throw this one in. When they came into the airline
industry, in particular,

they took customer
experience so seriously. You could be sitting in the
tightest, tiniest coach seat, and you liked it.

They had great entertainment. You got this little bag that
had a little rubber ducky in it. It was very clever. And across all their brands,
which is very much Branson,

don't take yourself
too seriously. So when you're starting to
think about the experience,

key questions to ask yourself. Does each customer interaction
live up to the brand experience

that the company is
trying to create? Think about it with the product. Think about it with a
marketing and sales effort.

Think about it with support. Think about it
with every aspect. And is that interaction
going to really live up

to what people expect
your brand to deliver? Are you providing a more
consistent and relevant

experience than your
competitors are? Go out and check it out. Because, again, chances
are at the end of the day,

your buyer is going to go with
those products are similar, I'll go with the one I
have the better customer experience with.

The other thing you see
happening often today is same situation, I'll
go with the one that has a greater corporate
social responsibility

mindset, which kind of
ties into the experience. It's one of the levers
of experience as well.

And then which interactions are
the most powerful for creating that customer loyalty?

And this is a construct
that a lot of companies use. It's called the customer journey
map, customer touchpoint map.

using the product, look for
where the moments of truth are. Where is it that I'm either
going to keep the customer

and they're going to go out and
give me great word of mouth? Or I'm going to completely fail? That's where I would have first
put my energy and my attention.

And then I could
work out, from there, to make everything just amazing. To make this happen, it
has to start at the top.

And this really hit me
when I first found it. This was part of the reason
Andrew Mason stepped down

as the CEO from
Groupon way back when. And I thought it
was so compelling that here you have a CEO, and
in his resignation letter, which

went viral, he admitted that he
didn't put the customer first.

He didn't think
about, what is going to make my customers really want
me, but more importantly, what

is that experience going
to be like as they interact with my product? My biggest regrets
are the moments

that I let a lack of data
override my intuition of what's best for our customers.

So have the courage,
start with a customer, and think about all the
experiences you are driving.

And if you are
forming a new company, or have the chance to influence
your existing company,

customer-focused
companies are those that give employee empowerment. Ritz Carlton is
another great example

of employee empowerment. They allow, I think
it's up to $1,000, that you allow any employee
to give back to a customer,

if they think it's going
to better their stay or their experience
with the brand. You want to hire for culture.

what are the company values? What is the culture? I wasn't scrambling to
find the card from HR. We lived those values, but we
also hired for them, as well.

Training investment--
super important. Leadership by
example, everyone has to believe the customer
experience, leaders on down.

People first attitude including
your own people, and then a customer service philosophy,
service in the big terms.

Not just that team
called support, that customer service is
what we're about, even if we're a hardware product.

All right, so key takeaways-- I hope this has been useful. We've tried to put a
whole lot of content

into a 40-45 minute
window so that we could have some great Q&A afterwards. And the key takeaways,
I hope you left with,

is no matter how
great your marketing is, it can't make up for a
lack of product market fit.

The whole product must be
considered when evaluating that product market fit. Not only the center, but all
my complementary services,

complementary products. Products fail when they aren't
compelling, don't meet needs, are too early to the market,
market isn't big enough,

and the product doesn't work. We can learn from history. And then customer experience
is key to differentiation.

So that's it. That's what I've got for you. I hope that was useful,
that you can apply it.

we have a question
from Michelle Cash. So how do we properly

to help define our product

Yeah, great question.

So a few words of
wisdom, first of all, make sure that you're actually
talking to clients that really

fit the market, going to
use two buzzwords here, the market and the persona
that you're going after.

I have seen people do client
interviews, very rich ones, but the problem was
at the end of the day,

they weren't really
their people. They weren't the

strategy work, I

start with what really
is my target market? Then I dive into who really
is that target audience,

that persona? And personas are used widely
across business-to-business, business-to-consumer,
business-to-developer-

marketing. So I want to make sure that
the people I'm talking to are the right people. Next thing is to make sure that
the questions you're asking

aren't leading the
witness, so to speak. You want to make sure that, this
is basic market research 101,

but again, I've seen
people, a lot of times, take these great
questions out to ask. And it's like, well,
you just steered him

in the direction of what

truthful, that they really

enable you to learn
and understand. And then I'm a big
fan, especially if I get either interaction
spot-on with a human,

talking to them, or I can use
a lot of open field questions if it's virtual,
that I really want

them to give me
as much feedback, in an open forum format. So yes, no, yeah, that
answers my question.

But I really want to hear, what
is the why behind their answer. So I try to structure
my interviews in a way

that I leave lots of
air time to really hear from that individual. And then I make

taken all that information,
I test it again. So it's that continuous circle. I've just learned
a lot, I've now

filtered it, factored
it into what I'm doing, and then I will go out and
have those conversations again.
